revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:De Re Aedificatoria.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Title page of 1550 edition, [[Florence]]]]
'''''De re aedificatoria''''' ('''''On the Art of Building''''') is a classic architectural treatise written by [[Leon Battista Alberti]] between 1443 and 1452.<ref>Cecil Grayson, in ''Kunstkronik'' '''213''' (1960:359ff, and ''Münchener Jahrbuch der Bildenden Kunst'' '''11''' (1960), demonstrated that the bulk of the composition was carried out between these dates.</ref> Although largely dependent on [[Vitruvius]]'s ''[[De architectura]]'', it was the first theoretical book on the subject written in the [[Italian Renaissance]], and in 1485 it became the first printed book on architecture. It was followed in 1486 with the first printed edition of Vitruvius.
==Book== [[File:L'architettura (1565) (14758258226).jpg|thumb|Plate from a 1565 edition, showing the plan of a [[basilica]]]] {{further|Mathematics and architecture|Mathematics and art}}
Alberti's ''Ten Books'' consciously echoes Vitruvius's writing, but Alberti also adopts a critical attitude toward his predecessor. In his discussion, Alberti includes a wide variety of literary sources, including [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], presenting a concise version of the [[sociology]] of [[architecture]]. ''De re aedificatoria'' is subdivided into ten books and includes:
* Book One: ''Lineaments'' * Book Two: ''Materials'' * Book Three: ''Construction'' * Book Four: ''Public Works'' * Book Five: ''Works of Individuals'' * Book Six: ''Ornament'' * Book Seven: ''Ornament to Sacred Buildings'' * Book Eight: ''Ornament to Public Secular Buildings'' * Book Nine: ''Ornament to Private Buildings'' * Book Ten: ''Restoration of Buildings''
In his survey of desirable floor plans for sacred buildings— "temples" in his phrase—Alberti begins with the ideal form of the circle, which is expressed in numerous examples of Nature. Nine ideal centrally-planned geometrical shapes are recommended for churches; besides the circle he lists the square, the hexagon, octagon, decagon and dodecagon, all derived from the circle, and, derived from the square, rectangles that exhibit the square and a half, square and a third and double square, all of which have enharmonic parallels in music. Chapels add small geometric figures to the basic circles and polygons to give a great variety of floor plans, in which each geometrical figure retains its clear unity and simple ratios that bind all elements of the plans and elevations into a harmonic unity.
''De re aedificatoria'' remained the classic treatise on architecture from the 16th until the 18th century.
==See also== *''[[De pictura]]''
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Alberti, Leon Battista. ''De re aedificatoria. On the art of building in ten books.'' (translated by Joseph Rykwert, Robert Tavernor and Neil Leach). Cambridge, Massachusetts: MIT Press, 1988. * Grafton, Anthony. ''Leon Battista Alberti: master builder of the Italian Renaissance.'' New York: Hill and Wang, 2000. * Tavernor, Robert. ''On Alberti and the Art of Building.'' New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 1998. * Wittkower, Rudolph. ''Architectural Principles in the Age of Humanism'' (London: Tiranti) 1962; (New York: Random House) 1965. Part I.i "Alberti's Program of the Ideal Church"; part ii "Alberti's Approach to Antiquity in Architecture"; part IV.iii "Alberti's 'Generation' of Ratios". * Fontana-Giusti, Gordana. 'Walling and the city: the effects of walls and walling within the city space', ''The Journal of Architecture'' pp 309–45 Volume 16, Issue 3, London & New York: Routledge, 2011 http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/rjar20/16/3#.UlGA8ChTNUQ
== External links == *[https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=89563736 Ten Books on Architecture by Leone Battista Alberti] *[http://architectura.cesr.univ-tours.fr/Traite/Auteur/Alberti.asp?param=en Latin, French and Italian editions of ''De re aedificatoria'']
{{Mathematics and art}}
[[Category:1485 books]] [[Category:Architecture books]] [[Category:Architectural theory]] [[Category:15th-century Latin books]] [[Category:Renaissance architecture]]

{{italic title}} In [[classical scholarship]], the '''''editio princeps''''' ([[plural]]: ''editiones principes'') of a work is the first printed edition of the work, that previously had existed only in [[manuscript]]s, which could be circulated only after being copied by hand.
For example, the ''editio princeps'' of [[Homer]] is that of [[Demetrius Chalcondyles]], now thought to be from 1488. The most important texts of classical Greek and Roman authors were for the most part produced in ''editiones principes'' in the years on either side of 1500, following the invention of the [[printing press]] around 1440.<ref name=Needham>{{cite book |title=Paper and Printing |author=[[Tsien Tsuen-Hsuin]] |author2=[[Joseph Needham]] |series=Science and Civilisation in China|volume=5 part 1|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=158,201|year=1985}}</ref><ref name=Briggs>Briggs, Asa and Burke, Peter (2002) A Social History of the Media: from Gutenberg to the Internet, Polity, Cambridge, pp.15–23, 61–73.</ref>
In some cases there were possibilities of partial publication, of publication first in translation (for example from Greek to Latin), and of a usage that simply equates with [[first edition]]. For a work with several strands of manuscript tradition that have diverged, such as ''[[Piers Plowman]]'', ''editio princeps'' is a less meaningful concept.
The term has long been extended by scholars to works not part of the Ancient Greek and Latin literatures. It is also used for legal works, and other significant documents.
==Latin works==
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Date ! Author, ''Work'' ! Printer !Location ! Comment |- |c. 1450<ref name="SW82">Michael F. Suarez and H. R. Woudhuysen (eds.), ''The Book: A Global History'', Oxford University Press, 2013, p. 82</ref> |[[Aelius Donatus]], ''Ars minor''<ref name="SW82"/> |[[Johannes Gutenberg]]<ref name="SW82"/> |[[Mainz]]<ref>Stephan Füssel, ''Gutenberg and the Impact of Printing'', Ashgate, 1997, p. 30</ref> |A very popular text: about 360 editions were printed in the 15th century, including nine surviving blockbook editions.<ref name="AG282">Anthony Grafton et al., ''The Classical Tradition'', Harvard University Press, 2010, p. 282</ref> |- |c. 1455 |[[Bible]] (Latin) |[[Johannes Gutenberg]] |[[Mainz]] |''[[Vulgate|Biblia Sacra Vulgata]]'', two editions: 42 line and 36 line, see [[Gutenberg Bible]]. |- |1463<ref name="PC-LCii458">Paolo Chiesa and Lucia Castaldi (eds.), ''Te.Tra. II. La trasmissione dei testi latini del Medioevo'', SISMEL, 2005, p. 458</ref> |[[Martin of Braga|Martinus Bracarensis]], ''Formula vitae honestae''<ref name="PC-LCii458"/> |[[Peter Schöffer]] and [[Johann Fust]]<ref name="PC-LCii458"/> |[[Mainz]]<ref name="PC-LCii458"/> | |- |1465<ref name="AG142">Anthony Grafton et al. 2010, p. 142</ref> |[[Cicero]], ''[[De Officiis]]'' and ''Paradoxa stoicorum''<ref name="AG142"/> |[[Johann Fust]]<ref name="AG142"/> |[[Mainz]]<ref name="AG142"/> |[[Ulrich Zell]] may have printed the ''De Officiis'' in Cologne (but not the ''Paradoxa''); but the Cologne edition does not bear any indication of date.<ref name="AG142"/> |- |1465<ref name="AG142"/> |[[Cicero]], ''[[De Oratore]]''<ref name="AG142"/> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="AG142"/> |[[Subiaco, Italy|Subiaco]]<ref name="AG142"/> |This edition was published without date but it is believed to be before September 1465.<ref name="AG142"/> |- |1465<ref name="MVA1608">[[Michael von Albrecht]], ''A History of Roman Literature: From Livius Andronicus to Boethius'', Leiden: Brill, 1997, p. 1608</ref> |[[Lactantius]], ''De opificio Dei'', ''Divinae Institutiones'' and ''De ira Dei''<ref name="MVA1608"/> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="MVA1608"/> |[[Subiaco, Italy|Subiaco]]<ref name="MVA1608"/> | |- |c. 1465<ref name="RLE318">Richard Leo Enos, ''The Rhetoric of Saint Augustine of Hippo: 'De Doctrina Christiana' and the Search for a Distinctly Christian Rhetoric'', Baylor University Press, 2008, p. 318</ref> |[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]], ''[[De doctrina christiana]]''<ref name="RLE318"/> |[[Johannes Mentelin]]<ref name="RLE318"/> |[[Strasbourg]]<ref name="RLE318"/> |This is thought to be the first edition of any of Augustine's works. The volume is incomplete as it has only the last of the four books that make up ''De doctrina christiana''.<ref name="RLE318"/> |- |1465–1470<ref name="FV7">{{it icon}} Franco Volpi (ed.), ''Dizionario delle opere filosofiche'', Mondadori, 2000, p. 7</ref> |[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]], ''[[Confessions (St. Augustine)|Confessiones]]''<ref name="FV7"/> |[[Johannes Mentelin]]<ref>Brian Cummings and James Simpson (eds.), ''Cultural Reformations: Medieval and Renaissance in Literary History'', OUP, 2010, vol. 2, p. 652</ref> |[[Strasbourg]]<ref name="FV7"/> |The second edition came out in [[Milan]] in 1475, followed by editions in 1482 and 1483. Other two incunable editions came from Strasbourg in 1489 and 1491, but the book was not separately reprinted until 1531.<ref name="HSS18"/> |- |1466<ref name="MDT2">Alasdair A. A. E. Enenkel and Wolfgang Neuber, ''Cognition and the Book: Typologies of Formal Organisation of Knowledge in the Printed Book of the Early Modern Period'', Brill, 2004, p. 221</ref> |[[Jerome]], ''Epistulae''<ref name="EN221"/> |Sixtus Riessinger<ref name="EN221"/> |Rome<ref name="EN221"/> |Edited by [[Teodoro de' Lelli]]. The issue of the ''editio princeps'' remains open as the imprint is undated, although believed to be about 1467; thus the 1468 Roman edition of the ''Epistulae'' printed by [[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]] and edited by [[Giovanni Andrea Bussi|Joannes Andreas de Buxis]] is also considered a possible first edition.<ref name="EN221"/><ref name="GAB">{{it icon}} M. Miglio. [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/giovanni-andrea-bussi_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/ "Bussi, Giovanni Andrea"], ''Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani''. Rome: Istituto dell'Enciclopedia Treccani.</ref> This book is probably the first to have been printed in Rome.<ref>{{it icon}} Arturo and Umberto Pregliasco, ''In domo Petri de Maximo: Mostra di incunaboli romani 1465–1477'', Rome: Libreria Philobiblon, 2008, p. 8</ref> |- |1467<ref name="JNF91">[[John Neville Figgis]], ''The Political Aspects of St. Augustine's City of God'', Forgotten Books, 1963 [1921], p. 91</ref> |[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]], ''[[City of God (book)|De Civitate Dei]]''<ref name="JNF91"/> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref>Robert H. F. Carver, ''The Protean Ass: The Metamorphoses of Apuleius from Antiquity to the Renaissance'', OUP, 2008, p. 162</ref> |[[Subiaco, Italy|Subiaco]]<ref name="JNF91"/> |The following year [[Johannes Mentelin]] printed in [[Strasbourg]] another edition; it offered the earliest textual commentary, by Thomas Valois and [[Nicholas Trivet]].<ref name="JNF91"/> For the next two centuries, the ''De Civitate'' was the most often printed of all Augustine's works; 17 editions appeared in the 15th century and eight in the 16th century.<ref name="HSS18">Harold Samuel Stone, ''St. Augustine's bones: a microhistory'', Univ. of Massachusetts Press, 2003, p. 18</ref> |- |1467<ref name="vives7">Juan Luis Vives, ''De conscribendis epistolis: Critical Edition with Introduction, Translation and Annotation'', Charles Fantazzi (ed.), Brill, 1997, p. 7</ref> |[[Cicero]], ''Ad familiares''<ref name="vives7"/> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="vives7"/> |Rome<ref name="vives7"/> |Sweynheym and Pannartz reprinted it in 1469; [[Johann and Wendelin of Speyer|Johannes de Spira]] published a new edition in 1469 in Venice.<ref name="vives7"/> |- |1467–1469<ref>Vergil Polydore, ''On Discovery'', Brian P. Copenhaver (ed.), Harvard University Press, 2002, p. 489</ref><ref name="GH318">Gilbert Highet, ''Juvenal the Satirist: A Study'', OUP, 1961, p. 318</ref> |[[Juvenal]]<ref name="GH318"/> |[[Ulrich Hahn (printer)|Udalricus Gallus]]<ref name="GH318"/> |Rome<ref name="GH318"/> | |- |c. 1468<ref name="AWP60">Alfred William Pollard, ''Fine Books'', Methuen, 1912, p. 60</ref> |[[Gregory the Great]], ''[[Commentary on Job|Moralia in Job]]''<ref name="AWP60"/> |[[Berthold Ruppel]]<ref name="AWP60"/> |[[Basel]]<ref name="AWP60"/> |Undated, it may be earlier than 1468, but not later.<ref name="AWP60"/> |- |1468<ref name="MVA1377">M. von Albrecht 1997, p. 1377</ref> |[[Festus (historian)|Festus]]<ref name="MVA1377"/> |Sixtus Riessinger<ref name="MVA1377"/> |Rome<ref name="MVA1377"/> | |- |1468<ref name="AUP13">{{it icon}} Arturo and Umberto Pregliasco 2008, pp. 13-15</ref> |[[Lactantius|Ps.-Lactantius]], ''De Ave Phoenice''<ref name="AUP13"/> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="AUP13"/> |Rome<ref name="AUP13"/> |This is the second edition of the works of Lactantius; it reprints the works of Lactantius and also contains [[Venantius Fortunatus]]' ''Carmen de Pascha'' and an excerpt from [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]''.<ref name="AUP13"/> |- |1468<ref name="moricca1229">{{it icon}} Umberto Moricca, ''Storia della letteratura latina cristiana'', SEI, 1928, vol. 2, p. 1229</ref> |[[Jerome]], ''De viris illustribus''<ref name="moricca1229"/> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref>Alan Coates, Kristian Jensen, Cristina Dondi, Bettina Wagner and Helen Dixon (eds.), ''A Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century Now in the Bodleian Library'', OUP, 2005, vol. 3, [http://www.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/48854/bod-inc_Volume_3_H.pdf p. 1271]</ref> |Rome<ref name="moricca1229"/> |Edited by [[Giovanni Andrea Bussi|Joannes Andreas de Buxis]] together with Jerome's ''Epistulae''.<ref name="moricca1229"/> |- |1469<ref name="ciceroxxv">Cicero, ''Orator'', Rolf Westman (ed.), Walter de Gruyter, 2002, p. xxv</ref> |[[Cicero]], ''[[Brutus (Cicero)|Brutus]]'' and ''Orator''<ref name="PAW285">Paul A. Winckler (ed.), ''Reader in the History of Books and Printing'', Greenwood Press, 1978, p. 285</ref> |[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="PAW285"/> |Rome<ref name="ciceroxxv"/> |Printed together with the ''[[De Oratore]]''.<ref name="ciceroxxv"/> |- |rowspan=2|1469<ref name="MVA1463">M. von Albrecht 1997, p. 1463</ref> |[[Apuleius]]<ref name="GAB"/><ref name="MVA1463"/> |rowspan=2|[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="GAB"/> |rowspan=2|Rome<ref name="MVA1463"/> |rowspan=2|Edited by [[Giovanni Andrea Bussi|Joannes Andreas de Buxis]]<ref name="GAB"/> Together with Apuleius' works, this edition contains the spurious ''Asclepius'' and a Latin translation of ''Epitoma disciplinarum Platonis'' by [[Alcinous (philosopher)|Alcinous]].<ref name="carver168">R. H. F. Carver 2008, p. 168</ref> |- |[[Pseudo-Apuleius]], ''Asclepius''<ref name="carver168"/><ref name="Gilly10">C. Gilly and C. Van Heertum (eds.), ''Magia, alchimia, scienza da '400 al '700: l'influsso di Ermete Trismegisto'', 2005, p. 10</ref> |- |rowspan=2|1469<ref name="MVA866">M. von Albrecht 1997, p. 866</ref><ref name="GBC375">Gian Biagio Conte, ''Latin Literature: A History'', JHU Press, 1999, p. 375</ref> |[[Livy]]<ref name="MVA866"/> |rowspan=2|[[Arnold Pannartz and Konrad Sweynheim|Sweynheym and Pannartz]]<ref name="MVA866"/> |rowspan=2|Rome<ref name="MVA866"/> |rowspan=2|Edited by [[Giovanni Andrea Bussi|Joannes Andreas de Buxis]].<ref name="GAB"/> The Rome edition included only Books 1–10, 21–32, 34–39 and a portion of 40. In a 1518 Mainz edition, the rest of Book 40 and part of 33 were published, while in a 1531 Basel edition, Books 41-45 were published, edited by [[Simon Grynaeus]]. He had discovered the only surviving manuscript of the fifth decade in 1527 while searching in the [[Lorsch Abbey]] in [[Germany]]. In 1616 the remaining part of Book 33 was published in Rome, by which all extant Livy had reached print.<ref name="GBC375"/><ref>M. von Albrecht 1997, p. 863</ref> |- |''[[Ab Urbe Condita (book)|Periochae]]''<ref>{{it icon}} L. The edition does not include all ten books of the ''Epistulae'' but only the first seven and the ninth, for a total of 122 letters of the currently existing 375. These were increased to 236 letters in nine books with the publication of the Roman edition in 1490. Still missing was the tenth book, found by [[Giovanni Giocondo]] between 1495 and 1500 in the [[Abbey of St. Victor, Paris|Abbey of St. Victor]] near Paris. Giocondo made a transcription, as did briefly after another Italian, Pietro Leandro, who once returned from France gave his partial copy of the tenth book to Girolamo Avanzi who printed the new 46 letters in [[Verona]] in 1502. For an edition of all Pliny's letters it was necessary to wait 1508, when [[Aldus Manutius]] printed in Venice a complete edition taking advantage of the transcript and other Plinian manuscripts Giocondo had given him.<ref name="MVA1155"/><ref name="LC"/><ref name="GGNV">{{it icon}} P. N. Successive separate editions of the text came from Rome in c. 1475, printed by Johann Schurener; [[Ferrara]], c. 1480; [[Naples]], also c. 1480, printed by Mattias von Olmütz; [[Perugia]], c. 1481, printed by Stephan Arndes; Rome, 1483, printed by Marcellinus Verardus; [[Leipzig]], c. 1495, printed by Konrad Kachelofen. The last of the incunable editions came out in [[Milan]] in 1500 by the humanist [[Janus Parrhasius]], who gave the text its first commentary. Also in the edition is [[Publilius Syrus]], whose ''Sententiae'' are in the so-called ''Proverbia Senecae''. The mistake was corrected in 1514 by [[Erasmus]] when the latter published in [[Southwark]] in 1514 an edition of Publilius that is generally considered to be the real ''editio princeps''. In 1643 Jacques Sirmond made a few further additions to the ''Genesis'', and [[Edmond Martène]] did the same in 1724 . In Paris in 1852, [[Jean Baptiste François Pitra]] in his ''Spicilegium Solesmense'' completed the ''Genesis'' and also first added ''Exodus'', ''Deuteronomy'' and ''Joshua'' plus parts of ''Leviticus'' and ''Numbers''. Pitra in 1883 in his ''Analecta sacra et classica'' published in Paris and Rome published further findings, i.e. the ''Book of Judges'' and new pieces from ''Leviticus'', ''Deuteronomy'' and ''Numbers''.<ref name="quastern4-312"/> |- |1560<ref name="paratore561">{{it icon}} E. A. de Honate<ref name="BDP"/> |rowspan=2|Milan<ref name="BDP"/> |rowspan=2|Edited by Bonus Accursius.<ref name="BDP"/> Undated, only Theocritus' first 18 idylls are contained in this edition.<ref name="AE2008-184"/> A wider arrange of idylls appeared in the 1495–1496 [[Aldine Press|Aldine]] Theocritus which had idylls I-XXIII.<ref name="NB01-51">N. Barker, ''The Aldine Press: Catalogue of the Ahmanson-Murphy Collection of Books by or Relating to the Press in the Library of the University of California, Los Angeles, Incorporating Works Recorded Elsewhere'', University of California Press, 2001, pp. 51-52.</ref> A further amount of yet unpublished idylls were printed in Rome together with their old ''scholia'' by [[Zacharias Calliergi]]s in his 1516 edition of Theocritus.<ref name="calliergi">{{it icon}} E. Mioni, [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/zaccaria-calliergi_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/ "Calliergi (Callergi), Zaccaria"], ''Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani'', vol. 16, 1973.</ref> |- |[[Theocritus]], ''Idyllia''<ref name="BDP"/><ref name="AE2008-184"/> |- |rowspan=5|1488–1489<ref name="calcondila">{{it icon}} A. Petrucci, [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/demetrio-calcondila_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/ "Calcondila, Demetrio"], ''Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani'', vol. 16, 1973.</ref> |[[Homer]]<ref name="calcondila"/> |rowspan=5| |rowspan=5|Florence<ref name="calcondila"/> |rowspan=5|Edited by [[Demetrios Chalkokondyles|Demetrius Chalcondyles]], the book was printed with the help of {{Interlanguage link multi|Demetrius Damilas|el|3=Δημήτριος Δαμιλάς}} that reelaborated the Greek types he had previously used in Milan. The editorial project was completed thanks to the financial support of [[Giovanni Acciaiuoli]] and the patronage of Neri and [[Bernardo de' Nerli]] ([[:it:Nerli|it]]) together with, the latter also author of an opening dedication to [[Piero the Unfortunate|Piero de' Medici]]. The edition included not only the ''[[Iliad]]'' and the ''[[Odyssey]]'', but also the so-called ''Homeric Hymns'', the ''Batrachomyomachia'' and passages on Homer from works attributed to [[Plutarch]], [[Herodotus]] and [[Dio Chrysostom|Dio Cocceianus]]. As for the typography the volume has traditionally been attributed to the prolific printer Bartolomeo de' Libri, attribution denied by recent scholarship. The issue thus remains unresolved.<ref name="calcondila"/><ref name="de' libri">{{it icon}} A. Cioni, [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/bartolomeo-de-libri_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/ "Bartolomeo de' Libri"], vol. 6, 1964.</ref><ref name="damilas">{{it icon}} C. This is because the manuscripts had fused ''Agamemnon'' and ''Choephoroe'', omitting lines 311-1066 of ''Agamemnon'', a mistake that was corrected for the first time in 1552 in the Venetian edition edited by [[Francesco Robortello|Franciscus Robortellus]].
